title: 107_s2844
content: The Act may be cited as the "Incentives to Educate American Children (I Teach) Act of 2002". Congress finds that there is a need for 2,000,000 new teachers in the next decade, especially in rural and high-poverty schools. Rural education is crucial in 25 states, and high poverty schools require special assistance to meet educational goals. The National Board for Professional Teaching Standards was established in 1987. The National Board for Professional Teaching Standards, founded in 1987, aims to establish high standards for accomplished teachers. Over 16,000 teachers from all states have completed certification, showing better performance compared to non-certified peers. Teacher salaries have stagnated over the past decade, with 2/3 of states below the national average. The Act aims to incentivize teachers to work in rural or high-poverty schools and provide tax credits for National Board certification to attract and retain qualified teachers. The Act introduces a tax credit for individuals teaching in high poverty or rural schools and certified teachers. A tax credit is allowed for eligible teachers in high poverty or rural schools, with an applicable amount of $1,000 for those serving in qualifying public schools. The tax credit for eligible teachers in high poverty or rural schools ranges from $1,000 to $2,000, depending on certification and school locale. Eligible teachers are defined as full-time kindergarten through grade 12 classroom teachers in public schools. Eligible teachers are defined as full-time kindergarten through grade 12 classroom teachers in public schools, with additional definitions provided for elementary and secondary schools and eligible academic year. Conforming amendments are also made to related sections of the Internal Revenue Code. Tax credit for teachers in high poverty or rural areas and certified teachers. Effective Date: Amendments apply to academic years ending in taxable years beginning after December 31, 2002.
